description: Ancient beyond mortal history, aboleths store every memory of their kin. Some claim they dream of rebuilding a world where gods never existed, lurking beneath the depths, whispering madness to surface minds.
Once-mortal spellcasters who defied death, liches fuel their unlife through a phylactery. Some say a lich remembers every soul it has ever destroyed, each voice echoing endlessly in its mind.
Wrapped in rotting bandages and cursed with eternal unrest, mummies are guardians of long-forgotten tombs. Their curse is said to linger in the air for centuries after they fall.
These unfortunate souls serve true vampires in eternal hunger. Some scholars note that a vampire spawn remembers its mortal life in vivid nightmares, cursed to crave what it once loved.
Born from hatred and unfinished vengeance, wraiths are pure shadow given form. Folklore claims that mirrors grow cold when one passes nearby, as if reality itself recoils.
Cunning and territorial, green dragons love manipulation more than gold. Rangers whisper that the forest itself bends to their will, concealing them in endless, toxic mists.
Often dismissed as beasts, white dragons are the apex predators of frozen realms. Their lairs are said to hum with the echoes of ice cracking — the dragon’s heartbeat itself.
Legends say sandstorms form around an Ancient Blue Dragon’s wings. Their lightning breath has been known to split mountains, and some desert empires still worship them as living gods.
Greed and fury incarnate, Ancient Red Dragons can ignite entire forests with a roar. Historians record wars fought solely to prevent their awakening from deep volcanic sleep.
Ancient White Dragons are embodiments of hunger and isolation. Frozen beneath centuries of ice, their hearts beat only when prey draws near — melting glaciers with every breath.
Balors embody chaos and flame. Ancient texts say a Balor’s death ignites an inferno that burns for days — a final curse on all who dared to strike it down.
Obsessed with hierarchy, Bone Devils carve infernal ledgers from mortal bone. Scholars suggest their claws etch secrets of souls they’ve condemned to eternal torment.
Chain Devils are said to weave their own bindings from the sins of mortals. In Hell, their rattling is considered a warning to lesser devils: pain approaches.
Once celestial warriors, Erinyes fell from grace but kept their beauty and discipline. Legends say their tears still burn with holy light that even Hell cannot quench.
Every blade a memory of war, Mariliths are tacticians among demons. They remember every battle they’ve fought, claiming that losing even once stains their very essence.
Rakshasas claim their reflections show their true selves — a tiger’s sneer beneath a human mask. Some tales say they can only die at the hands of those they wronged.
Alchemists believe Basilisks don’t see — they sense life. Some keep vials of its blood, claiming it can petrify any potion it touches. Few have survived to test the theory.
Behirs are jealous of dragons and hoard lightning instead of gold. Their stomachs can hold prey for weeks, digesting both metal and magic with ease.
Chimeras dream constantly, each head with a different nightmare. Scholars suggest they experience three lives at once, never agreeing which one is real.
Cloakers communicate through eerie harmonics. Some bards believe their howls contain ancient songs that predate the mortal tongue itself.
Each Hydra head thinks independently. One wizard recorded a hydra arguing with itself for a full hour before realizing it was alone.
Medusas can’t see their own reflections — or they’d turn to stone. Some say this blindness grants them prophetic dreams of those who gaze upon them.
Minotaurs can remember every turn they’ve ever taken in a maze. They never get lost — only their prey does.
Purple Worms carve new tunnels with every breath. Some dwarves consider them miners — unintentional ones that leave treasure veins exposed in their wake.
Trolls regenerate endlessly, but some sages claim they feel every lost limb regrow — reliving their last wound forever.
Wyverns can fly for days without rest. It’s said they sleep only midair, trusting the winds to carry them home.
Forged with the blood of its creator, an Iron Golem’s breath is the sound of molten metal cooling. Some kingdoms keep one as a crown’s final guardian.
A Shield Guardian links its life to its master’s amulet. Some wander for centuries after their master dies, still searching for orders that will never come.
Runes carved into a Stone Golem’s skin glow brighter when it moves. Some inscriptions contain spells no mortal has ever translated.
Cloud Giants keep gardens in the sky. Some claim they grow crops of lightning and thunder for their stormy feasts.
Fire Giants measure honor in perfect weapons. They say a blade should be flawless enough to reflect its maker’s regrets.
Frost Giants duel to decide leadership — in blizzards so fierce that even gods are said to turn away until it ends.
Storm Giants claim to hear the whispers of the ocean’s heart. Their anger can summon hurricanes; their laughter, rainbows.
Each Ettin head dreams its own dreams, and the two rarely agree. Travelers say that at night, their arguments echo for miles, warning all nearby that madness roams the hills.
Planetars serve as divine generals, their voices able to calm armies or split the heavens. Some ancient texts say a Planetar’s tear can cleanse even infernal corruption.
Oni delight in deception, feeding on dreams and fear alike. Some villages hang mirrors at their doors, believing Oni can’t stand to see the truth reflected back.
Dragon Turtles are ancient sea lords, feared by sailors for capsizing fleets. Some ocean tribes revere them as the living anchors that hold the world’s waters steady.
Forged from infernal flame, Hell Hounds hunt in silence. It’s said their footsteps leave scorch marks that never cool, even after the beast itself has perished.
Invisible Stalkers exist only to obey. Bound to service, they never rest until their task is complete — even if centuries pass, they always find their quarry.
Sailors swear that the Kraken remembers every ship it’s ever sunk. Some even claim the ocean’s deepest currents are its veins, pulsing beneath the world itself.
